title-group.article-title: UK paramedics can legally withhold resuscitation in defined circumstances

body.p: We write in response to the study of ‘Paramedic experiences and expectations concerning advance directives: A prospective, questionnaire-based, bi-centre study’ by Taghavi et al.1 The article incorrectly states that it is not legally clear cut whether UK ambulance clinicians may withhold resuscitation, in the presence of an ‘advance directive’ or a Do Not Attempt Resuscitation (DNAR) form.

In England and Wales, the Mental Capacity Act (2005)2 has made it possible for individuals to complete legally binding Advance Decisions to Refuse Treatment (ADRT). Like any treatment, cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) can be refused in an ADRT. If ambulance clinicians practising in England and Wales are presented, in a timely manner, with a valid and applicable ADRT refusing CPR, statutory law would require them to respect this.

The finding by Taghavi et al.1 that paramedics experience uncertainty regarding legal aspects of practice matches with previous literature.3 It is important therefore to highlight that in the United Kingdom, ambulance clinicians can be assisted in making resuscitation decisions through the UK ambulance service clinical practice guidelines4 issued by the Joint Royal Colleges Ambulance Liaison Committee (JRCALC).

The current guideline issued in 2011 includes a section about DNAR orders and ADRTs. It sets out that in addition to certain categorical situations known to be incompatible with life, UK ambulance clinicians are permitted to withhold resuscitation when

list-item.p: A formal DNAR order is in place …
The patient is in the final stages of a terminal illness where death is imminent and unavoidable and CPR would not be successful, but for whom no formal DNAR decision has been made
An Advance Decision (Living Will) has been accepted by the treating physician (patient’s GP or hospital Consultant) as a DNAR order.4

body.p: Overall, if UK ambulance clinicians are called to patients who have an easily accessible and identifiable ‘advance directive’, in the form of an ADRT refusing CPR or a DNAR decision, the ambulance clinicians do have legal frameworks and professional guidance to support them to make a decision to withhold resuscitation, provided they believe these documents are relevant to the current situation.

In 2010, a regional online end-of-life education programme for ambulance personnel was established, which has to date been completed by 2600 clinicians in the West Midlands Ambulance Service. Early reports have indicated that after this education, ambulance clinicians felt more confident in deciding when not to resuscitate, and the experience of community professionals suggests that inappropriate and futile resuscitation attempts are becoming more uncommon.
